chapter.title: Install Software
chapter.para: Ubuntu is based on Debian which has the most advanced package management system written to date. Installing software with Ubuntu is quite different from what you might be used to, usually you don't have to search for programs (or packages as it is usually called on Linux), all you need is just a few mouse-clicks away. Here we will explain three ways to install software. This might look overly complicated but, as always, people have different tastes and needs. The first method is the new installer. It is called . Many people will only use this tool. It is the easiest way to install all your basic software. If you do a lot with packages (the term that we will use from now on), then Synaptic will be the next step. Synaptic has it's own manual so we will only shortly describe it here. And then the third way, the command-line tools. Now you might object that you don't want to type anything! That's ok, you don't have to, you can do all you need with synaptic, but if you like to make things really complicated, or do really complicated things (all depends on your point of view), or just don't like using the mouse, then there are the command-line tools, apt, dpkg and friends.

All the tools described above use the same underlying system, so you do not have to worried that over time your system will become unstable, just because you install or remove packages. Actually you'll notice that you might start to install and remove packages just to check them out. It's just that easy.

sect1.title: Fast and Easy
sect1.para: The icons and short descriptions help you to quickly find the requested package. By pressing ... you select it and by pressing ..., it will get installed. You'll see a window popping telling you what it is doing but you can safely ignore this. In a couple of seconds (depending on what you just installed and how fast your network connection is), you'll be able to start your application from the menu. The most difficult part is actually finding it in your menu. For the rest: easy as pie.

sect1.title: Using advanced tools
sect1.para: Don't let the title scare you off. Using the advanced tools for pakage management is not that hard. Actually if you are used to using the simpler tools then you have a basic understanding already of what is going on. The following tools will give you more power to have more fine-grained control over what you are doing:
The Synaptic package manager is a powerfull tool for package-management. Documentation to it you can find here.
And then there are the command line tools. These are the most powerfull but to use these you have to understand wht is going on. Documentation can be found here.
